summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons Office of Internal Affairs referral to the DOJ OIG regarding the death of Jeffrey Epstein at MCC New York on August 10, 2019. It details allegations against two correctional staff for failing to conduct required inmate counts/rounds, leading to an investigation for endangering inmate safety, inattention to duty, and failure to follow policy.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell in the Special Housing Unit at MCC New York at approximately 6:33 a.m. CPR was administered, and he was transported to a hospital where he was pronounced dead at 7:36 a.m.

events.title: Failure to Conduct Inmate Counts
events.description: Two correctional staff members (a Correctional Officer and a Materials Handler Supervisor) failed to conduct the mandatory 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. inmate counts/rounds in the Special Housing Unit where Epstein was held.

events.title: Internal Affairs Referral to OIG
events.description: The Bureau of Prisons Office of Internal Affairs formally referred the incident to the Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General for investigation, citing allegations of endangering inmate safety, inattention to duty, and failure to follow policy.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell at MCC New York on August 10, 2019, at 6:33 a.m. and pronounced dead at a hospital at 7:36 a.m.
Two BOP staff members—a Correctional Officer and a Materials Handler Supervisor—admitted to failing to conduct the mandatory 3 a.m. and 5 a.m. inmate counts/rounds on the night of Epstein's death.
One of the officers stated 'we messed up' and 'I messed up, she's not to blame we didn't do any rounds' during the initial inquiry.
The involved staff claimed they were 'traumatized' by the event, requested to go home, and wanted their union president to review any statements they had to write.
The BOP Office of Internal Affairs referred the case to the DOJ OIG, alleging misconduct including endangering inmate safety, inattention to duty, and failure to follow policy.
